column13: London Convention Scientific Group
column14: The London Convention and Protocol Scientific Groups are responsible for the provision of scientific and technical advice in relation to the London Convention and Protocol, respectively.
column15: Scientific Initiative

column13: The Circulate Initiative Impact Metrics Working Group
column14: The Circulate Initiative (TCI) exists to incubate, measure, and amplify solutions to preventing plastics waste in our oceans (focus in South East Asia).
column15: Scientific Initiative

column13: EU Marine Strategy Framework Directive (MSFD) Technical Group on Marine Litter
column14: A group of EU Member State Experts on Marine Litter together with the European Commission (DG ENV, DG MARE, JRC and others) and other stakeholders. The group is advising the MSFD implementation by developing harmonised approaches, providing guidance and discussing best approaches on monitoring, assessment and measures, acting as science-policy interface. The group is chaired by France, Germany and the JRC
column15: Scientific Initiative
column59: Transnational (several countries are involved, including bilateral)
column61: Denmark;Austria; Belgium; Bulgaria; Croatia; Cyprus; Czechia; Denmark; Estonia; Finland; France; Germany; Greece; Hungary; Ireland; Italy; Latvia; Lithuania; Luxembourg; Malta; Netherlands; Poland; Portugal; Romania; Slovakia; Slovenia; Spain

column13: EU Scientific Advisory Mechanism
column14: The Scientific Advice Mechanism is a service created by the European Commission which provides independent science advice directly to European Commissioners to inform their decision-making. The SAM has published a report on the environmental and healths risks by microplastics. Currently work on the biodegradability of plastics in the Environment is in progress.
column15: Scientific Initiative
column59: Transnational (several countries are involved, including bilateral)
column61: Denmark;Austria; Belgium; Bulgaria; Croatia; Cyprus; Czechia; Denmark; Estonia; Finland; France; Germany; Greece; Hungary; Ireland; Italy; Latvia; Lithuania; Luxembourg; Malta; Netherlands; Poland; Portugal; Romania; Slovakia; Slovenia; Spain

column7: Scientific Committee on Oceanic Research; U.S. National Science Foundation; Richard Lounsbery Foundation
column13: Scientific Commitee on Ocean Reseach (SCOR) - Working Group 153: FLOATSAM
column14: A working group in SCOR to address the problem of floating litter at the global scale by disentangling coastal processes (with their short timescales) from the open ocean low-frequency processes, to improve the application of ocean circulation models to the drift of debris at sea, and to assess and promote the use of remote sensing tools to study floating debris at sea.
column15: Scientific Initiative

column13: Packaging plastics in the circular economy
column14: EASAC brings together the National Science Academies of the EU Member States, Norway and Switzerland. It is the voice of independent science advice, mobilising Europe's leading scientists to guide EU policy for the benefit of society. EASAC has published a report which reviews the negative consequences of the current linear economy for plastic packaging, the scope for improvement towards a more circular pattern of production and use, and options for increasing recycling rates and reducing leakage into the environment.
column15: Scientific Initiative
column59: Transnational (several countries are involved, including bilateral)
column61: Denmark;Austria; Belgium; Bulgaria; Croatia; Cyprus; Czechia; Denmark; Estonia; Finland; France; Germany; Greece; Hungary; Ireland; Italy; Latvia; Lithuania; Luxembourg; Malta; Netherlands; Poland; Portugal; Romania; Slovakia; Slovenia; Spain;Switzerland;Norway

column13: Plastics in Polar Environments Action Group (PLASTIC-AG, SCAR)
column14: Scientific Committee of Antarctic Research (SCAR) has a Plastics in Polar Environments Action Group, officially approved by SCAR in 2018. The AG focusses on addressing scientific questions around distribution of plastics in Polar environments, their sources and fates, their impact on Polar ecosystems, and the potential for remediation or mitigation.
column15: Scientific Initiative

column13: Scientific Committee of the Interntional Whaling Commission
column14: The SC of the IWC reviews regularly research reports on marine litter and microplastics and its impacts on cetaceans, resulting in recommendations to improve the situation. In 2019, a workshop on Marine Debris was hold resulting in a long list of recommendations, including remediation measures and mitigation actions.
column15: Scientific Initiative

column7: Comission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources(CCAMLR)
column13: Intersessional Correspondence Group on Marine Debris (ICG-MD), Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR)
column14: The CCAMLR Marine Debris program was established in 1989 to monitor debris levels in the Convention Area, with specific regard to fishing debris items, as a response to increasing concerns regarding global marine debris levels. The Intersessional Correspondence Group on Marine Debris (ICG-MD) was created in 2019 to review and revise the Marine Debris program.
column15: Scientific Initiative

column7: Carribean Region - Marine Litter Regional Working Group
column13: Carribean Region - Marine Litter Regional Working Group
column14: One of the Actions part of the Marine Litter in the Wider Caribbean Action Plan is to establish a Caribbean Marine Litter Regional Working Group to co-ordinate and advise on appropriate actions for marine litter management.
column15: Scientific Initiative

column13: East Asian Seas
column14: The Coordinating Body on the Seas of East Asia (COBSEA) working group on marine litter
column15: Scientific Initiative

column13: NBO Convention
column14: Marine Litter Regional Technical Working Group in the Western Indian Ocean Region
column15: Scientific Initiative

column13: International Convention for the Prevention of Pollutiuon from Ships
column14: The MARPOL Convention was adopted on 2 November 1973 at IMO. The Protocol of 1978 was adopted in response to a spate of tanker accidents in 1976-1977. As the 1973 MARPOL Convention had not yet entered into force, the 1978 MARPOL Protocol absorbed the parent Convention. The combined instrument entered into force on 2 October 1983. In 1997, a Protocol was adopted to amend the Convention and a new Annex VI was added which entered into force on 19 May 2005. MARPOL has been updated by amendments through the years.
column15: Scientific Initiative

column13: Runder Tisch Meeresmüll
column14: The main objective of the platform is to provide organisational support for the German Roundtable on Marine Litter and its working groups. In addition, the public part of the platform serves public relations work and the bundling of information on marine litter. The Ecologic Institute developed this central German portal on marine litter technically, structurally and graphically to support the fulfilment of the tasks of the Marine Strategy Framework Directive with regard to marine litter and other international obligations (e.g. Action Plan on Marine Litter, OSPAR, HELCOM).
column15: Scientific Initiative

column7: Group of Experts on the Scientific Aspects of Marine Environmental Protection (GESAMP)
column13: GESAMP working group 38
column14: Atmospheric Input of Chemicals to the Ocean. Working Group 38 was formed in 2008 because of growing concern about the impact of atmospheric deposition of both natural and anthropogenic substances on ocean chemistry, biology, and biogeochemistry as well as climate.
column15: Scientific Initiative

column7: Group of Experts on the Scientific Aspects of Marine Environmental Protection (GESAMP)
column13: GESAMP working group 40
column14: Working Group on the sources, Fate and Effects of plastics and micro-plastics in the marine environment.
column15: Scientific Initiative

column7: Group of Experts on the Scientific Aspects of Marine Environmental Protection (GESAMP)
column13: GESAMP working group 43
column14: Sea-based sources of marine litter. Following an agreement in principle at the 45th annual session of GESAMP in 2018, the Working Group on sea-based sources of marine litter (WG 43) was established formally in April 2019. The overall objective of WG 43 is to build a broader understanding of sea-based sources of marine litter, in particular from the shipping and fishing sectors, including the relative contribution of different sources, analysis of plastic use and management within both industries and the range and extent of impacts from sea-based sources of marine litter.
column15: Scientific Initiative

column7: Western Indian Ocean Marine Science Association (WIOMSA)
column13: Marine and Coastal Science for Management (MASMA) programme
column14: MASMA was established to reduce predominance of narrowly focused natural science research, limited emphasis on interdisciplinary research, and limited attention to the critical links between science and the larger societal issues in the region. Consequently, MASMA seeks to strengthen applied and interdisciplinary research on both the natural and social science aspects of coastal environmental issues for the purpose of advancing knowledge that is directly relevant to society and resource management.
column15: Scientific Initiative
column59: Transnational (several countries are involved, including bilateral)
column61: Somalia; Kenya;United Republic of Tanzania, Mozambique, South Africa, Comoros, Madagascar, Seychelles, Mauritius, France

column7: University of Nairobi; University of Surrey
column13: Governing Plastics Network
column14: The Governing Plastics Network is organised by the University of Nairobi in Kenya and the University of Surrey in the UK and is funded by UK Research and Innovation (UKRI) through the Global Challenges Research Fund (GCRF). The network works with policy makers, scientists, NGOs and other stakeholders in Ethiopia, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania and Uganda and comprises two linked two-year projects.
column15: Scientific Initiative
column59: Transnational (several countries are involved, including bilateral)
column61: United Kingdom of Great Britain & Northern Ireland; Kenya

column13: NOWPAP Regional Action Plan on Marine Litter
column14: The NOWPAP Regional Action Plan on Marine Litter was adopted in 2008. The 2020 NOWPAP Marine Litter Focal Points Meeting was organized on 3 December 2020 virtually to discuss how to revise the NOWPAP Regional Action Plan on Marine Litter.
column15: Scientific Initiative
column59: Transnational (several countries are involved, including bilateral)
column61: China; Japan; Republic of Korea;Russian Federation

column13: UNEP/MAP CorMon Marine Litter
column14: Ecosystem Approach Correspondence Groups on Monitoring Marine Litter (CorMon Marine Litter)
column15: Scientific Initiative

column7: Comission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources(CCAMLR)
column13: Intersessional Correspondence Group on Marine Debris (ICG-MD)
column14: Development of an approach to use current data holdings to measure changes in debris levels and to quantify levels of debris in the CAMLR Convention Area -integration of opportunistically collected data by other members, organisations, etc. -incorporation of new methodology in line with globally accepted standards -expansion of monitoring efforts to capture spatial and temporal trends.
column15: Scientific Initiative
